Production of polyalfaolefin-based lubricants using new (poly)ionic liquid /AlCl3 catalysts as environmentally friendly alternatives to commercial AlCl3 route Miad Mashayekhi a Saeid Talebi a Samahe Sadjadi b Naeimeh Bahri-Laleh c * a Faculty of Polymer Engineering, Sahand University of Technology, P.O. Box: 51335-1996, Tabriz, Iran Faculty of Polymer Engineering Sahand University of Technology P.O. Box: 51335-1996 Tabriz Iran Faculty of Polymer Engineering, Sahand University of Technology, P.O. Box: 51335-1996, Tabriz, Iran. b Gas Conversion Department, Faculty of Petrochemicals, Iran Polymer and Petrochemical Institute, PO Box 14975-112, Tehran, Iran Gas Conversion Department Faculty of Petrochemicals Iran Polymer and Petrochemical Institute PO Box 14975-112 Tehran Iran Gas Conversion Department, Faculty of Petrochemicals, Iran Polymer and Petrochemical Institute, PO Box 14975-112, Tehran, Iran. c Polymerization Engineering Department, Iran Polymer and Petrochemical Institute (IPPI), P.O. Box 14965/115, Tehran, Iran Polymerization Engineering Department Iran Polymer and Petrochemical Institute (IPPI) P.O. Box 14965/115 Tehran Iran Polymerization Engineering Department, Iran Polymer and Petrochemical Institute (IPPI), P.O. Box 14965/115, Tehran, Iran. ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Aiming to decrease corrosive AlCl3 dosage in polyalphaolefin production, two new (poly)ionic liquid /AlCl3 catalysts were synthesized from the reaction of 1-vinylimidazole with benzyl chloride (to yield IL) and subsequent polymerization of its vinyl bond by radical route, to achieve polyionic liquid (PIL). Cationic oligomerization of three α-olefin monomers, from 1-hexene to 1-decene, was accomplished using IL(or PIL)/AlCl3 catalysts with 50:50 wt.% composition to halve the usage of hazardous AlCl3. Microstructure and flow characteristic of the obtained PAO oligomers were characterized by 1HNMR, 13CNMR, GPC, viscometry, GC-Mass, and SimDis analyses and compared with those of PAOs from neat AlCl3. Results from GPC, viscometry and GC revealed that molecular weight decreases using lighter α-olefin monomers. Notably, while the PAOs from IL/AlCl3 have almost heavier fractions, the ones from PIL/AlCl3 and neat AlCl3 demonstrated similar molecular weight and KV100 amounts. The PAOs from PIL/AlCl3 and IL/AlCl3 represented a more uniform structures, with low short chain branching, beneficial to higher viscosity index (VI). This achievement featured PIL/AlCl3 as a suitable alternative to corrosive AlCl3, which besides its more environmentally friendly character, thanks to PIL presence, is capable of producing PAOs with the same KV100, however, with much higher VI values. Keywords Polyalfaolefins Lubricant Ionic liquid Cationic polymerization 1 Introduction Polyalphaolefin (PAO) based lubricants are recognized as the most commonly used synthetic based oil in automotive and high-performance engine oils applications [1–4]. It has all hydrocarbon structure, without double bonds, ring structures, S and N containing components or waxy hydrocarbons. The non-polar nature of PAOs, together with their high viscosity index (VI, >130), good oxidation stability, low pour point and good compatibility with mineral oils make them prominent candidates in engine oil topic, at both low and high temperature applications [5–7]. PAOs are commercially produced via a three-stage process including oligomerization, hydrogenation and distillation [8]. To synthesize PAOs, a wide range of α-olefin monomers from C6 to C12 are usually employed. In this regard, a variety of oligomerization catalysts, including coordination catalysts [9–12], Lewis acid catalysts [13–15], liquid coordination complexes [16], and ionic liquid (IL) [17] systems were reported for the PAOs synthesis. Amongst the reported catalytic systems, BF3- and AlCl3-donor are still the dominant catalysts to produce general grade PAOs [18]. Despite their high efficiency in cationic oligomerization of α-olefins, both BF3 and AlCl3 have corrosive and hazardous nature, which stimulate the research groups to think about alternative catalysts for this process or at least decrease catalyst dosage in the reaction medium. In this regard, we focused on novel methods for supporting AlCl3 on different carriers, such as alumina, silica, alumina/ FeCl3 and silica/FeCl3. It was found that while single supports increase kinematic viscosity (KV), mixed ones decrease it [13]. In another study, Hogg et al. reported new IL catalysts based on pyridine or picoline and BCl3 moieties as alternatives to corrosive neat BF3. They could tune the catalytic activity by changing the substituents on the cation, the nature of the anion and reaction temperature [17]. Ding et.al. employed another IL system based on 1-butyl-3-methyl imidazolium and AlCl3. Their studied catalysts could perform 1-decene oligomerization in a good yield of 74 % [19]. Considering the reported results on the IL containing catalysts, one can recognize their significant impact on the oligomerization performance, due to their unique charge distribution character. Actually, ILs are regarded as low melting point, low toxic organic salts with high electric conductivity [20–22]. They are composed of both cationic (mostly heterocycles or quaternary ammonium structures) and anionic (almost inorganic compounds) moieties [20,23]. Use of ILs in both industry and academia has witnessed significant growth [24–29]. Recently, we have reported the utility of IL/AlCl3 catalytic systems for the oligomerization of 1-decene and the effect of the nature of IL on the features of the final PAO [30]. The results indicated that IL/ AlCl3 can be considered as an alternative for AlCl3. Those promising results motivated us to pursue our studies on this topic. In this research we aim to study and compare the efficiency of IL/AlCl3 and PIL/AlCl3 for the oligomerization of various monomers. More precisely, one IL, synthesized from the reaction of 1-vinylimidazole with benzyl chloride and one PIL, derived from polymerization of the as-synthesized IL by AIBN were prepared. The synthesized IL and PIL together with AlCl3 were then used in the cationic oligomerization of three monomers, including 1-hexene, 1-octene and 1-decene. Subsequently, the synthesized PAOs were fully characterized by 1HNMR, 13CNMR, GPC, viscometry and GC analyses to unravel the structure-properties relationship. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material and instruments All the employed chemicals, including 1-vinylimidazole, benzyl chloride, azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN), 1-hexene, 1-octene, 1-decene, hexane and AlCl3 were purchased from Merck Co, Germany and used as received. 2.2 Synthesis of IL For the synthesis of IL, 3 mL of 1-vinyl imidazole was reacted with 3.8 mL benzyl chloride in 20 mL of methanol as solvent. The mixture was stirred at 70 ℃ under argon atmosphere for 24 h. The highly viscous product was washed with 20 mL diethyl ether and dried at 50 °C in an vacuum oven (Scheme 1 ) 2.3 Synthesis of PIL For the polymerization of IL and synthesis of PIL, 1 g of IL and 20 mL of toluene were added to a flask, in which 0.03 g of AIBN was added under N2 atmosphere. The mixture was stirred at 70 ℃ for 3 h. At the end of the reaction, the polymer product was separated from the solution, washed repeatedly with methanol and consequently dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C, overnight. 2.4 Oligomerization of α-olefins α-olefin oligomerizations were carried out according to the literature [31]. Typically, a stainless steel reactor containing 0.45 g of AlCl3 catalyst was purged with argon gas. 0.45 g of the as-synthesized IL or PIL together with 5 mL of dry hexane were introduced to the reactor and the temperature was raised to 60 °C. The mixture was stirred for 8 min and then α-olefin (30 g) monomer together with H2O (in AlCl3/H2O = 2.0 M ratio) were fed to the reactor. The reaction temperature was elevated to 100 °C and the reaction was continued for 1 h under stirring. Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled down, and the produced oil was evacuated, washed three times with 5 wt.% of NaOH solution and vacuum distilled to evaporate unreacted monomers and water. The specifications and labels of the produced oils were gathered in Table 1 . 2.5 Characterization 13CNMR and 1H-NMR spectra were recorded by Bruker DRX400 MHz NMR spectrometer in CDCl3 solvent at 25 °C. In recording 13CNMR spectra, pulse angle, delay time, and the number of scans were kept at 90˚, 6 s, and 6000, respectively. Kinematic viscosity at 100 and 40 °C (KV100 and KV40) and viscosity index (VI) were measured as stated in ASTM D445 and ASTM D2270, respectively. GPC instrument (GPC Agilent 1100) was used to determine molecular weight and the distribution of the synthesized PAOs using CHCl3 solvent and flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. The boiling point and carbon number of the synthesized PAOs were obtained using HT-CNS SimDis instrument (Agilent 7890 A gas chromatograph equipped with FID, NCD, and SCD and AC Simulated Distillation Software) combined with a detailed hydrocarbon analyzer (DHA, Agilent 7890 A Gas Chromatograph with FID and AC DHA Software). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of IL and PIL Synthesis of IL and its polymerization to PIL were done according to well-known procedures [32,33], therefore their characterization was escaped here. In this regard, we were satisfied by viscosity change from a low viscous liquid to a honey like viscous material in IL synthesis, and material state change from viscous liquid to solid particles in PIL synthesis stages. 3.2 Optimization of AlCl3 loading To optimize catalyst dosage as the most important factor in determining reaction yield, oligomerization of 1-decene was conducted in the presence of different amounts of AlCl3 catalyst, Fig. 1 . The obtained results declared that the oligomerization yield increases by AlCl3 amount from 1 to 2 and 3 wt. %. However, a further increase in the catalyst dosage decreased oligomerization activity, may be due to the agglomeration of the AlCl3 particles in the reaction pool. In fact, higher productivity was obtained at AlCl3 dosage of 3 wt. %, therefore this amount was selected as the optimum value. 3.3 Oligomerization performance of IL and PIL catalysts Oligomerization of different α-olefin monomers, from 1-hexene to 1-decene, was conducted using the as-synthesized catalysts according to the reaction conditions of Table 1. In all experiments, the same amount of the catalyst (3 wt. %), with IL(or PIL)/AlCl3 weight ratio of 50:50, was employed. Using the so called weight ratio, AlCl3/IL molar ratio becomes 1.7. This amount was selected according to the previously published literature, which showed that AlCl3/IL molar ratio of ∼2 is appropriate for these systems [16,19]. Neat AlCl3 was also utilized as the blank system. In this line, PIL/AlCl3 catalyst performed oligomerization reactions with slightly lower yields; however, AlCl3 and IL/AlCl3 demonstrated the same product yields, which imply no noticeable negative effect of the IL and PIL in the composition of the catalytic system. It has already been reported that ILs can catalyze oligomerization of α-olefins [34]. However, in our case, individual IL and PIL could not initiate α-olefin oligomerization. About the impact of IL/PIL as catalytic ingredient we believe that they can bind to the AlCl3 catalyst and change the environment of released H+ either by its stabilization or destabilization, however, the general scheme of the cationic oligomerization of α-olefins by these materials does not change. Indeed, this is similar to the role of donors in liquid coordination complexes [16]. 3.4 Molecular weight and viscosity results To ascertain the effect of IL and PIL on the molecular weight characteristic of the PAOs, GPC analysis was considered. According to the results of Table 2 , neat AlCl3 furnished 1-hexene, 1-octene and 1-decene oligomers with Mn = 980, 1410 and 1730 g/mol, respectively. It is clear that by increasing the α-olefin length from C6 to C8 and C10, molecular weight increases as well. This trend was observed in IL/AlCl3 and PIL/AlCl3 catalytic systems, too. Moreover, the synthesized PAOs from IL/AlCl3 catalyst demonstrated high molecular weight value, where PIL/AlCl3 did not alter Mn, considerably. It evidences that charge distribution in IL makes AlCl3 a weaker acid. It is well accepted that weaker acids release less active H+, the initiator of cationic polymerization, which yields oligomers with longer main chain [35]. Notably, AlCl3 and IL cannot release H+, active for α-olefin oligomerization initiation. However, the combination of AlCl3 and H2O, used as donor, yields acidic H+ in the oligomerization bath. We believe that, the presence of IL or PIL can affect the strength of released H+, which is a dominant factor in determining PAO molecular weight. Furthermore, all PAOs have narrow PDI, thanks to the efficiency of the catalysts and reaction conditions, which is beneficial in the commercialization step since they give almost monodisperse products (Fig. 2 ). KV40 and KV100 characteristic of the as-synthesized oils were measured by viscosity analysis, Table 2. They are considered as the most important features, which affect the flow characteristic of an oil. In fact, one expects high VI from a suitable engine oil in the industry. This feature stimulates the formation of a thick hydrodynamic film between the surfaces, where the oil was applied, at high temperature and guarantees good flow properties at low temperature [13]. In this regard, the PAO with high VI has less tendency toward viscosity changes with temperature [36]. According to the viscosity results of Table 2, PAOs from neat AlCl3 and PIL/AlCl3 catalytic systems exhibited almost identical KV100 values; however, IL/AlCl3 achieved PAOs with high KV values, in good agreement with Mn results. Also, VI was improved by IL and PIL presence in the composition of oligomerization catalysts. Indeed, PIL/AlCl3 produced PAOs with the same molecular weight as it is in the neat AlCl3, nevertheless, with much more VI which is fruitful for less viscosity difference with temperature. This outcome has its route in the short chain branching (SCB) feature [37] which will be discussed later. Moreover, VI demonstrated the following order in the synthesized PAOs: poly1-decene > poly1-octene > poly1-hexene, using all the catalytic systems, due to the increased molecular weight by monomer length, together with the variation in SCB, vide infra. As a short consequence to this part, it is noted that PIL/AlCl3 exhibited PAO with almost similar Mn and KV100 values compared to those of the oils from neat AlCl3, however, with much higher VI amounts. This affirms that PIL/AlCl3 not only renders an environmentally friendly catalytic system, by reducing the amount of hazardous and corrosive AlCl3, but also it harvests PAO with significantly improved fluidity. 3.5 End unsaturation of the synthesized PAOs In the next step, the type of C = C moieties was explored by 1HNMR spectroscopy, Fig. S1. In fact, vinylic H region at δ = 4.80–5.40 ppm was analyzed to individualize the share of vinylene (Vn and 2Vn), trisubstituted vinylene (3Vn) and vinylidene (Vd) structures from the unsaturation content, Table 3 . Worth mentioning, Vn, Vd and 3Vn are afforded from 1,2-inserted chain end, while 2,1-inserted chain end causes the formation of 2Vn structure (Scheme 2 ) [9,30]. In the obtained results, no clear trend was discovered for the catalyst type and monomer length at all. However, excellently, in all as-synthesized PAOs, no CH2 CHR structure was detected. This moiety yields a mono-substituted chain after PAO hydrogenation which is detrimental to PAO viscosity index. In contrast, 3Vn was the dominant CC structure which is resulted from a 1,2-insertion mechanism. Worth mentioning, branched CC moieties are favorable for PAO flow-ability. The ratio of CH2+CH hydrogens to CH3 hydrogens (HCH+CH2/HCH3) of the synthesized PAOs was also included in Table 3. It is clear that this amount decreases by moving from 1-decene oligomers to 1-octene and 1-hexene oligomers, in accordance with the number of carbon atoms of the monomeric units. 3.6 Branching type and content results from 13CNMR The type of branching, as one of the primary structural data, has significant impact on the VI properties. Next, the branching type and amount of the synthesized PAOs were examined through 13CNMR together with DEPT spectroscopy analyses, Figs. S2 and S3, respectively. The peaks at δ = 14.0, 22.8, 29.0–30.6, and 32.1 ppm were assigned to the end CH3 group, α-CH2, β-CH2, and δ-CH2 [38,39], respectively. Some multiple peaks at δ = 26.7 and 34.4 ppm were attributed to the first carbon atom in the side chain, while peaks located at δ = 28.0 and 32.7 ppm were appointed to CH3 moiety in the short chain and long chain, respectively [39]. Also, Distortionless Enhancement by Polarization Transfer (DEPT) method was used to identify the carbon type as (CH3), methane (CH), quaternary carbons and methylene (CH2) [40], in which the peaks under base line is an assign of CH2 moieties, Fig. S3. The collected results from 13CNMR and DEPT-135 analyses were gathered in Table 4 . It includes the type and share of CH3 moiety in a different atomic environment which causes the appearance of peaks at unique chemical shifts, between δ = 10.80–22.6 ppm. As reported in Table 4, the presence of either IL or PIL in the catalyst composition had a significant effect on the microstructure of the synthesized PAOs by increasing long chain branching (LCB, the sum of entries 3 and 5) amounts. In another meaning, the share of inner CH3 branches, i.e. short chain branching (SCB, the sum of entries 2, 4, 6, 7 and 8), decreased in IL/AlCl3 and PIL/AlCl3 catalytic systems. It has a direct effect on VI values so that the more LCB content, the higher VI value, which is equal to less viscosity difference at various temperatures [38]. Furthermore, PAOs from 1-decene monomer demonstrated higher LCB amounts in all studied catalytic systems, due to the more C atom in the side chain of the monomer unit. Amongst the studied systems, IL-Dec and PIL-Dec represented the highest LCB amounts of 83 and 81 %, respectively. On the other hand, AlCl3-Hex demonstrated the lowest LCB value, in agreement with its lower VI (see Table 2) In the following, SCB and branching ratio (BR) of the oligomers were further evaluated using the formula 1 and 2 [41]: (1) branching ratio = 15 × ∑ C 13 integral 11 − 17 ppm / 15 × ∑ C 13 integral 11 − 17 ppm + 14 × ∑ C 13 integral 18 − 44 ppm (2) short-chain branching percentage = ∑ C 13 integral short-chain methyl / ∑ C 13 integral all methyl × 100 The results from these formulae were in good agreement with the results of Table 4 (based on the type of SCB and its percentage), where: i) IL/AlCl3 and PIL/AlCl3 catalysts resulted in PAOs with lower SCB and BR, ii) the SCB and BR amounts changed by monomer type as the following order: 1-hexene > 1-octene > 1-decene. It can be deduced from this section that PAOs from PIL/AlCl3 and IL/AlCl3 catalysts have more uniform structures, thanks to the IL and PIL presence, which reflected its impact on higher VI of PAOs. This featured the designed catalysts as much capability-enhanced ones, regarding commercialized AlCl3 catalyst, which can produce the PAOs with almost the same KV100 amounts, but with much improved VI (Table 5 ). 3.7 PAO fractionation by boiling point In the last part of this study, fractionation of the synthesized PAOs was performed by GC analysis to get information about the dimer, trimer, tetramer and > tetramer contents. The assignment of peaks at a given elution time was accomplished according to literature [15]. It was revealed that all synthesized oligomers had a continuous number of carbon atoms since broad peaks were obtained in GC curves. According to the fractionation results summarized in Table 6 , neat AlCl3 and PIL/AlCl3 demonstrated PAOs with almost the same number of monomer units, in which the share of > tetramer was more than di-, tri- and tetra-mer. Furthermore, oligomers from 1-decene and 1-hexene monomers had more and less heavy fractions, i.e. > tetramer, respectively which originates from the molecular weight of the starting monomer. Moreover, among the studied systems, AlCl3-Hex and PIL-Hex revealed a higher share of lighter PAOs, nearly 47 % of ≤ trimer fractions. It affirms that the number of repeating units in the oligomer backbone can be tuned by monomer selection and catalyst design. Interestingly, GC results were in good agreement with Mn obtained from GPC analysis. And finally, simulated distillation (SimDis) curves of the studied PAOs were surveyed, Fig. 3 . These data were obtained from the combination of a high-performance capillary gas chromatograph with a simulation distillation software. Also, to better analyze the SimDis curves, initial boiling point (iBP), final boiling point (fBP), and the temperature at which 10, 50 and 90 % of PAO is evaporated (denoted as T10, T50 and T90, respectively) were derived, Table 7 . All SimDis curves exhibited a broad peak, in which the initial boiling point was almost higher than 300 °C, and nearly 99.5 % of the chains evaporated before 750 °C in all as-synthesized PAO samples. Low waxy polymer content of 0.5 wt. % at final boiling point (in the range of 740−758 °C) affirms oligomeric structure of the produced chains. Furthermore, IL-Dec and AlCl3-Hex (or PIL-Hex) exhibited the highest boiling point and the lowest boiling point fractions, respectively, in all mass regions, which is an indication of their high and low Mn values, respectively. Moreover, the overall results, including T10, T50 and T90 were almost in line with Mn data from GPC and oligomer distribution results. 4 Conclusions Aiming to decrease the dosage of corrosive AlCl3 catalyst in PAO production, IL was synthesized from the reaction of vinylimidazole with benzyl chloride which subsequently polymerized with AIBN initiator to achieve PIL. The synthesized IL and PIL were employed together with AlCl3 (in 50:50 weigh ratio) in the cationic oligomerization of a series of α-olefin monomers, from C6 to C10. The structural configuration of the synthesized PAOs, ascertained as KV, VI, long chain and short chain branching, varied mostly by monomer length and in somehow by catalytic system design in which neat AlCl3 and PIL/AlCl3 achieved PAOs with the same molecular weight but different SCB value, while IL/AlCl3 yielded high viscosity chains with lower SCB content. A significant achievement of the designed PIL/AlCl3 catalyst, besides halving the corrosive AlCl3 dosage, was the same molecular weight amount of the resulted PAOs, together with noticeable increase in VI values. It is an excellent improvement in PAO characteristics and implies the high performance of the produced oils towards temperature change, which is an important issue in PAO final usage. CRediT authorship contribution statement Miad Mashayekhi did all experiments and analyses. Saeid Talebi served in editing the manuscript. Samahe Sadjadi helped in conceptualization, Methodology and editing the manuscript. Naeimeh Bahri-Laleh has role in conceptualization, funding acquisition, supervision, Methodology and writing and editing of the manuscript. coredata.dc:description: Aiming to decrease corrosive AlCl3 dosage in polyalphaolefin production, two new (poly)ionic liquid /AlCl3 catalysts were synthesized from the reaction of 1-vinylimidazole with benzyl chloride (to yield IL) and subsequent polymerization of its vinyl bond by radical route, to achieve polyionic liquid (PIL). Cationic oligomerization of three α-olefin monomers, from 1-hexene to 1-decene, was accomplished using IL(or PIL)/AlCl3 catalysts with 50:50 wt.% composition to halve the usage of hazardous AlCl3. Microstructure and flow characteristic of the obtained PAO oligomers were characterized by 1HNMR, 13CNMR, GPC, viscometry, GC-Mass, and SimDis analyses and compared with those of PAOs from neat AlCl3. Results from GPC, viscometry and GC revealed that molecular weight decreases using lighter α-olefin monomers. Notably, while the PAOs from IL/AlCl3 have almost heavier fractions, the ones from PIL/AlCl3 and neat AlCl3 demonstrated similar molecular weight and KV100 amounts. The PAOs from PIL/AlCl3 and IL/AlCl3 represented a more uniform structures, with low short chain branching, beneficial to higher viscosity index (VI). This achievement featured PIL/AlCl3 as a suitable alternative to corrosive AlCl3, which besides its more environmentally friendly character, thanks to PIL presence, is capable of producing PAOs with the same KV100, however, with much higher VI values.
coredata.dc:title: Production of polyalfaolefin-based lubricants using new (poly)ionic liquid /AlCl3 catalysts as environmentally friendly alternatives to commercial AlCl3 route
